docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Gunmen Kill At Least 5 In Attack on Israeli Settlers Palestinians killed at least five Israeli settlers, a mother and three children among them, in a raid in Itamar, a settlement near Nablus. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine took responsibility. The attack came as Israeli soldiers spread throughout the West Bank, enforcing a new policy to seize Palestinian land in reprisal for Palestinian suicide bombings. A1 British Cutbacks in Afghanistan Britain will soon begin withdrawing more than 1,400 troops involved in the hunt for Al Qaeda and Taliban forces in Afghanistan. A11

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists working with human embryonic stem cells have converted them into the type of brain cell that is lost in Parkinson's disease, and have shown that the equivalent cells in mice alleviate Parkinson-like symptoms in rodents. ''What we are showing here is that we absolutely, definitely have the right cell,'' said Dr. Ron McKay, a stem cell biologist who works at the National Institutes of Health.

headline.main: Progress Is Reported on Parkinson's Disease

docs.abstract: Article on National Institute of Health study in which researchers working with human embryonic stems cells were able to convert them into type of dopamine-producing brain cell that is lost in Parkinson's disease; researchers have also shown that equivalent cells from mice alleviate Parkinson-like symptoms when transplanted into rats; Dr Ron McKay comments (M)
docs.snippet: Scientists working with human embryonic stem cells have converted them into the type of brain cell that is lost in Parkinson's disease, and have shown that the equivalent cells in mice alleviate Parkinson-like symptoms in rodents.    ''What we are...

docs.lead_paragraph: As lawmakers battle over a prescription drug bill, pharmaceutical and health-care concerns are providing major support for a fund-raiser scheduled for Wednesday night that is expected to raise more than $20 million for Republican candidates in this year's Congressional election. Sponsors of the event, which features a speech by President Bush, include GlaxoSmithKline, the multinational drug giant, as well as others in the pharmaceutical industry, a Republican official said.

headline.main: Drug Makers Sponsor Event For G.O.P. as Bill Is Debated

docs.abstract: Drug and health-care companies are providing major support for Republican fund-raiser even as lawmakers debate prescription drug bill; event features speech by Pres Bush; Sen Bill Frist's letter to potential donors stresses aim of regaining Senate control to 'relax the stranglehood of rules' on business; his photo (M)
docs.snippet: As lawmakers battle over a prescription drug bill, pharmaceutical and health-care concerns are providing major support for a fund-raiser scheduled for Wednesday night that is expected to raise more than $20 million for Republican candidates in this...

docs.lead_paragraph: Physical abuse in childhood is associated with a wide variety of problems in later life -- a fact documented by decades of research. Abused children are more likely as adults to suffer from depression, to abuse alcohol or drugs, to commit crimes and to develop chronic health problems, among other things.

headline.main: Physically Abused Children Recognize the Face of Anger

docs.abstract: Study led by University of Wisconsin researcher Seth Pollak, published in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences, concludes that children repeatedly explosed to adult rage and physical abuse appear to develop heightened sensitivity to faces that change gradually from sadness or fear to anger; also finds that when such children are around people who behave more rationally, their perceptual systems fail to make shift and may develop interpersonal difficulties (M)
docs.snippet: Physical abuse in childhood is associated with a wide variety of problems in later life -- a fact documented by decades of research.    Abused children are more likely as adults to suffer from depression, to abuse alcohol or drugs, to commit crimes...

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients who will benefit from antidepressants may show telltale changes in the electrical activity of their brains weeks before they enjoy any relief from their symptoms, researchers have found. The findings may eventually be useful to doctors treating some severely depressed patients and to researchers developing drugs to treat depression, said the lead author, Dr. Ian A. Cook of the University of California at Los Angeles.
docs.abstract: Researchers at University of California at Los Angeles, reporting in Neuropsychopharmacology, find patients who will benefit from antidepressants may show telltale changes in brain electrical activity weeks before symptoms are relieved; drawing (M)
